reviewText: I saw this movie several times in the past and could not pass up the opportunity to see if Blu-ray would contribute much.This is a unique approach to the life and contributions of Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart. It is told through the filter of an acquaintances' Antonio Salieri (F. Murray Abraham) of who struggle with god. In addition, we seeing the movie of course may miss some of the play but being a movie we have replaced them with visions of Prague, where the movie was filmed.The only thing that can be a bit annoying to some people is the laughing style they gave Mozart (Tom Hulce) in this production.Be sure to watch the extra information where the different actors and the director tell about the trials and tribulations of getting a film crew in to Prague 1984 and having to deal with the secret police.Get a different view of the play in Midsomer Murders: The Death of a Hollow ManMidsomer Murders: The Death of a Hollow Man

reviewText: I saw this movie in the theatre 6 times when it came out in 1984 (when I was about 13).  Now, in late 2004 I saw it again for the first time in exactly 20 years.  And I'm still overwhelmed.  Little did I know Hollywood can produce something this classy.The sound and picture are quite satisfactory in quality.  The extra 20 minutes don't really add much to the story, though the film now requires (I think) an R-rating as a result.I don't know if Salieri killed Mozart.  I doubt it though.  Still, from my reading, there is ample evidence to suggest that Salieri really was Mozart's secret enemy, and that he created as many employment hurdles for Mozart in the Viennese court as he could.  If true, then this means the real Salieri did play a role in Mozart's poverty after all.  So why am I not surprised no one cries out loud about character-assassination.  The fellow was a creep whether or not he killed Mozart.  And a lousy composer besides.  No tears for Salieri from me, but many for Mozart.The irony is not lost on me.  Tom Hulce, who played the title-role with such consummate skills (plus real piano finesse) won no Oscar for being a Supporting Actor.  Murray Abraham, on the other hand, won the Best Actor.  Now, I agree Abraham was superb in this film (though some of it was helped by the fanatastic makeup).  But to me Hulce lost out big time.  I mean, they gave this film Oscars for Sound, Art Direction, Adapted Screenplay and what not - but for Hulce, nothing at all.  Sounds familiar, anyone?  A Mozart tragedy was repeated in real life, by - of all things - the film about Mozart.

reviewText: Amadeus is one of my favorite films, it's sumptuous and funny and expansive and epic, yet personal and poignant.After seeing the theatrical cut at least a half dozen times, I was lucky enough to see the Director's Cut at the Cinerama Dome in Los Angeles when it first debuted, and while it is longer (by at least 20 minutes) the cut scenes seem to have only been done for total run time NOT for pacing or redundant information.A key, key, key scene between Stanzi and Salieri is restored that really adds a deeper twist to their relationship when he comes calling near the end wanting the Requiem. it's hard to believe it was cut at all (unless it was for rating). There are some other nuance scenes that are strong too, but aren't critical (yet are still delicious, I won't spoil them, you just need to see this version).F. Murray Abraham can a career performance, and so did Tom Hulce. I don't know if Milos Foreman surpassed this; perhaps Cuckoo's Nest is his chef d'oeuvre but I like and enjoy this more.

reviewText: I found that the film was not at all as I expected- a staid Merchant-Ivory type production mixed with a hint of Masterpiece Theater. This was both good and bad. On the positive side is the very dramatic structure of the film, being told from Mozart's inferior rival's, Antonio Salieri's (F. Murray Abraham), point of view. On the down side is the over the top performance by Tom Hulce, as Mozart, especially with that pointlessly distracting guffaw. Also, as the DVD delineates which scenes were altered, extended, or added in toto, it becomes obvious that director Milos Forman's original cut was the superior, as none of the added scenes adds palpably to the thrust of the film. Yes, I liked the added scene of Mozart's wife, Constanze (Elizabeth Berridge), getting naked to try to sexually please Salieri, to advance her husband's career, for Berridge was certainly a major hotty with the body back then, but, despite my prurient interest, the scene is pointless.... Unfortunately, in either version, this is nowhere near a great film. It's a fun, solid romp, but the American accents and slang that infiltrate Eighteenth Century Viennese society are just too much, as is Hulce as Mozart. No, a staid portrayal of the man would have been dull, but a genius as idiot savant, or a step above, is not worthy of this dramatic treatment, either. That it only heightens Salieri's frustration is dramatically defensible, but since the whole notion of Salieri's envy and hatred of Mozart is a historical fiction, there really was no reason to go so over the top in the first place.The rest of the cast does fairly well. Berridge as the clueless wife, Jeffrey Jones, as Emperor Joseph, is a dolt with a heart, who doesn't understand how to run his own life, much less a nation....All in all, I would recommend the film, but as a light diversion, not a serious inquiry in to art nor the artistic mindset. That film has yet to be made.

reviewText: Erstmal danke für diese Neuauflage. Auch ich ( Jahrgang 1973 ) bin stark von diesem Film begeistert, seitdem ich ihn damals das 1x im Kino sah, alte Fassung. Die Musik hier ist keine Nebensache, wie sonst üblich, sondern im Grunde sogar so etwas wie der ungenannte, dennoch immer präsente " 3. Hauptdarsteller ".Nicht umsonst wurde ja schon oft gesagt, das man den Film rund um die Musik aufgebaut hat, nicht andersherum, wie es normalerweise den Regelfall darstellt. Natürlich kann man hier nicht wirklich von wahren Begebenheiten bzw. echter Authentizität sprechen, aber für jeden, der so überhaupt ein gesteigertes Interesse an klassischer Musik und dem echten Mozart bekommt, weiterhin absolut empfehlenswert.Für die Erzählstruktur des Filmes und seiner Geschichte aber war die Idee, das ganze " so " ...Salieri beschreibt in Rückblicken lediglich aus seiner Sicht die Dinge, wie sich sich zugetragen haben sollen. Er, als ein neidischer, - bedeutend älterer Konkurrent des jungen, aufstrebenden und ( zu der Zeit nur für ihn zweifellos ) viel talentierteren Mozart, der allerdings privat nur ein vulgärer Clown ist.... abzuhandeln jedenfalls grundsätzlich nicht verkehrt gewesen. Alles andere, kann man nachlesen.Sie unterhält bestens und fesselt den Zuschauer bis zum Ende. Auch aus der Kameraperspektive. Die Einstellungen, wenn beide zu sehen sind, wurden immer so gewählt, als stehe man direkt daneben. Man empfindet so sehr schnell Sympathie, Mitleid, zumindest Verständnis für Mozart. Obwohl Salieri ja der " Star " im Film sein soll. Auch etwas, das die Presse ( der Film wurde insgesamt für 8 Oscars nominiert, ebenso für beide Hauptdarsteller, gewonnen hat ihn aber am Ende nur F. Murray Abraham ) dazu veranlaßte, es dem Film " komform " so darzustellen, als hätte Salieri 200 Jahre später nochmal über Mozart gesiegt.Die Wahrheit sieht allerdings anders aus. Und genau das macht den Reiz dieses Film's aus, sich anschließend erstmal richtig mit dem Thema zu beschäftigen.Vom DC hier wußte ich bis jetzt eigentlich noch garnichts, obwohl er schon seit 2002 verfügbar ist. Dennoch ist es interessant, durch die nun wieder eingefügten Szenen, zu erfahren, woher die große ( besonders, am Ende gezeigte ) Antipathie zwischen Constanze und Salieri herrührte ... oder auch, so in einer alternativen Einstellung dargestellt, das ein vermutliches Verhältnis zwischen der Sängerin Caterina Cavalieri und Mozart sich für Salieri nun völlig anders offenbarte.Was ja auch sein späteres Hauptmotiv gewesen sein mag für erstgenannte, neue Szene. Dadurch das, - nur als Beispiel, diese beiden bisher fehlten, wird die ganze Handlung nun nochmal etwas dramatischer. Näheres ( Achtung, - Spoiler ! ) dazu ist im Schnittbericht zu erfahren. Auch anderes fügt sich nun mit ein, das dem Film sogar ergänzend nur zugute kommt.Was aber auch sein gutes hat, denn dadurch sind inzwischen etliche Synchronvergleiche ( auch auf Video, also zum reinhören ) im Netz. Bei Salieri ist die neue Stimme leider eine Zumutung ... ging aber nicht anders, weil ja sein ursprünglicher Sprecher bereits verstorben ist. Daher auch nur der eine Stern Abzug. W. Amadeus selbst aber z.B., oder auch der Kaiser Joseph II. und Constanze Weber - Mozart klingen alle wie gehabt.Schikaneder, Baron van Swieten, Hofkapellmeister Bonno, Graf Orsini - Rosenberg, - von Strack sowie einige Nebendarsteller sind gewöhnungsbedürftig. Ihre Stimmen kommen zwar in etwa hin, aber auch deren Sprecher altern eben. Insgesamt ist auch der Ton hier generell etwas schwächer und weniger kraftvoll geraten als es so noch in der alten Fassung war. Trotzdem wurde sich sehr viel Mühe gegeben. Und wie es sich für eine BluRay gehört, das Bild ist natürlich bedeutend besser als bei der bisherigen DVD Auflage.Im Grunde kann man also nur feststellen, das, wer die alte Kinoversion nicht kannte, sich leichter darauf einlassen wird. Uns älteren Fans allerdings wird immer etwas dabei " fehlen " ... ( verständlicherweise, - denn der Mensch ist ja bekanntermaßen nunmal ein Gewohnheitstier ).Die Empfehlung, sich das ganze einfach in der Original Tonfassung anzuschauen ist unzutreffend. Einfach weil es sich hierbei um die Geschichte eines europäischen Künstlers handelt und auch der gesprochene Wiener Schmäh' sehr gut dazu paßt. Im Gegenteil, schon schlimm genug, das ab und zu mal englisch gesungen wurde.Fazit: alte DVD ( Kinofassung ) aufheben, und die neue Fassung bei Bedarf auf BD nachkaufen ( gebraucht, günstig ). Sorry, nun ist es fast eine rein subjektive Rezension statt einer objektiven geworden. Aber wem diese Informationen trotzdem bei seiner Kaufentscheidung weiter helfen sollten, warum nicht. Viel Vergnügen.
summary: Amadeus, Director's Cut ... auch als Premium Edition verfügbar

reviewText: I would always give the original Amadeus that I saw at the theater a 5 star all the way. I think it is among the top 10 musical plays ever. The so-called Director's Cut editions work for some films. Unfortunately, the extra scenes don't add much to the movie, and I feel like skipping them altogether when watching it (unless you want to watch Elizabeth Berridge strip before Salieri - I'm not offended by the scene, but it just makes the movie longer without making a point out of it - the audience already knows that Salieri has carnal desires like any other men by watching the theatrical release). I wonder why WB didn't offer an alternative on the DVD, and only shows us with the most recent version. I wonder if my feeling toward the film would have been the same, had I seen this version. Nevertheless, I enjoy the film regardless of these unnecessary alterations.

reviewText: What more can be said about this classic?  This is one of my favorite movies of all time.  The direction, acting, sets, music, ALL superb.  The Director's Cut stretches the length to neary 3 hours but it goes by quickly.  It looks and sounds great on Blu-ray and if you're a fan you should upgrade from DVD.  The use of Mozart's music set to certain scenes of the film is superb (like every time the mysterious masked man appears).  The scenes of the operas are amazing.  For a film about the demise of one of our greatest composers there is a surprising amount of humor as well.  Movies don't get better than this.
summary: One of the Greatest Movies EVER

reviewText: Great liberties are taken with the biographical details of Mozart and Salieri's lives to create a morality play about jealousy in this enduring and stunning period film. AMADEUS won eight Oscars in 1985: Best Actor in a Leading Role (F. Murray Abraham), Best Art Direction, Best Costume Design, Best Director, Best Makeup, Best Picture, Best Sound, and Best Writing (adapted), as well as four Golden Globes, among numerous other awards and nominations. While the biographical details are altered, it seems that the sets, props, and costumes, all depict late 18th century Germany and Austria in stunning fidelity. F. Murray Abraham's portrayal of Antonio Salieri is one of the best performances I've seen in modern movies and (I think) influenced the likes of Anthony Hopkins and Gary Oldman.Milos Forman restored 20 minutes to the theatrical cut in 2001 to make his 180 minute director's cut, which was restored and transfered to a special edition two-disc DVD set in 2002 and this 2009 BD. The special features also carry over. This BD is identical to the one in the DigiBook edition, sans the CD and Digital Copy, which were superfluous for me since I have several CDs of Mozart's music and wouldn't watch this film on a smaller screen.The video quality of the BD certainly improves on the artifact-laden DVD, richly displaying the colorful sets and costumes of AMADEUS as they were intended to appear. I hardly noticed any DNR; generally details are very clear. Audio quality is also boosted with an excellent Dolby TrueHD 5.1 surround track that accurately represents the space and action of every scene and highlights the music with tremendous dramatic effect.With the excellent MAKING OF AMADEUS documentary included it is easy for me to replace the old DVD with this new BD, even if the DVD packaging is more refined (and informative, as it notes where footage has been restored). I can also highly recommend this modern classic to everyone, since we can all relate to Salieri's "mediocrity," while enjoying a very fine HD transfer.
summary: Badly behaved voice of God vs. patron saint of mediocrities.

reviewText: "Amadeus" is not rated R, it's rated PG. Don't believe me? Check elsewhere. Why in the world would you put R? There is very little adult situations, little violence, and little language. Believe me movie fnas. It's rated PG. The following is an edition to this review. Now, I understand why the rating change came to be. The Director's Cut has 20 minutes of new footage which contains nudity. Why did Milos Forman decide to put a deleted dirty scene back into a great picture. Because of that the whole MPAA rating changed. If you love this movie, and you are unhappy with the new director's cut, buy the original theatrical release. I own that one and not the director's cut(Thank God). For a minute there I got scared and thought they just changed the rating for the fun of it. You'll be happier with the original. I predict a plunge in the sales of the director's cut.

reviewText: There's no need to review the merits of this movie. The only question is whether 1. you like the longer Director's Cut, which is the version included in this Blu-Ray Book, and 2. if it's worth upgrading from DVD to Blu-ray.Taking the second question first -yes! The BD is an improvement over the DVD, and the Blu-Ray Book packaging is a nice upgrade as well.As far as the theatrical release v the Director's Cut, I like the DC. Some think it makes the movie too long. I don't. It reminds me of the old joke told in orchestral circles: an American attends a concert in Vienna. When asked how he liked it, he answers, "it was OK...maybe a little on the long side." To which his Viennese friend replies, "I see. But you must realize that here in Vienna, we love music."Recommended.

reviewText: Milos Foreman's earlier work, "One Flew over the Cuckoo's Nest" holds the distinction of being the only movie, along with Frank Capra's "It Happened One Night", to receive all five major academy awards - Best Picture, Director, Actor, Actress, and Screenplay. Great as that earlier work is and all that just recognition and honor it received, the fierce sadness of this tale of madness, both individual and institutional, is almost too much to bear. The terrible fate of McMurphy (Nicholson) at the hands of Nurse Ratched (Louise Fletcher) is hardly compensated by that final glimpse of freedom for McMurphy's closest friend. But it is only in this later Milos Foreman classic, "Amadeus", this adaptation of Peter Shaffer's tale of "genius", that Foreman seems to be addressing the more redeeming consequences of this unsettling, and unsettled theme, this meeting of institutional madness and individuals within it who aspire to escape that influence.The forms of madness we are introduced to here, primarily in Antonio Salieri's (played by F. Murray Abraham) malicious ways against the humane and creative example of Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart (played by Tom Hulce), is no less harmful than Nurse Ratched's. In Ken Kesey's novel the institutional onslaught, through its key representative, Nurse Ratched, strips down the rights of individuals until they are completely stifled. There is quite literally no air to breathe for its protagonist and the result is a claustrophobic emptiness. Milos Foreman's adaptation of Peter Shaffer's "Amadeus" is no less sparing in its dramatization of institutional forces and the peculiar madness of its key representative, Salieri. While Salieri wants the creativity of Mozart's genius to flower, it is only for the selfish purpose of rabidly appropriating those works under his name. The goal is to entrap that incandescent activity of genius, to tap and transfer that light, and have that shine through him. It is an equally lethal form of imprisonment that destroys the protagonist of "Amadeus".The unique testament of "Amadeus", however, is that the artist, his art, and his unrelenting spirit of creation, can conserve lofty sentiments, ideals and counter the influence of a Machiavellian, like Salieri. Foreman has to tell this story given the stranglehold of institutional madness and its triumph over human helplessness that is the story of the previous film."Amadeus" begins with the consequences of Salieri's devious ways. He is shown as an aged, repentant, inconsolable, and reptilian character, in an insane asylum. It is thus a tie-in to the world of Nurse Ratched from Foreman's previous tale of madness. Salieri has attempted suicide. As he recovers he recounts his tale to a young priest. His is a story of an aspiring artist who gives the best years of his life in its service only to be cruelly upstaged by a man of real genius. Salieri recounts his early pact with God. It is an act that belies his crudeness, his arrogance, and what is worse, his more prosaic understanding of God. It is no surprise that God flees from the drab soul of the man and chooses to move through the more rarified soul and music of Mozart. How could the music that Salieri imagines himself composing emerge from the trapped, sterile, and insecure soul of a fawning courtier?Salieri should have followed his father's counsel and been a "businessman". His commitment to God betrays a stunted notion of art borne out of a satanic pride and a crude understanding of divine ways. The language of business permeates his most private conversations with God. His prayers never go beyond conditions: the "if-then" craft of his begging prayers have a ferocity and primitiveness to it. Even the language of prayer constricts into the wooden form of a legal contract in Salieri's soul. It is no surprise, then, that the art that Salieri produces is similarly pedestrian. It cannot soar with God's presence, as he so desperately wants it to. His music sputters and takes on the language and form of the courts. It is courteous, measured, mannered, and resonates with the decorum of his king's court. Indeed he is a courtier, through and through, and hardly an artist.Salieri's commitment and austere vows notwithstanding, the God and the muses of music descend on the unsuspecting soul of a prodigy in Salzburg. Mozart is touched by the divine hand, that Salieri so craves, at an early age, and his prolific output brings early recognition and honor in Joseph II's courts. The sheer facility with which the young Amadeus cranks out his tunes does not dilute the high quality of his musical accomplishments. Salieri is a terrible musician. But he has the eye of a gifted critic. He is a silent admirer of Mozart's genius. He knows a good tune when he hears it. When Amadeus's music is played it soars miraculously, just as he dreamed his own music would. Salieri cannot help but smile at Mozart's performances. In these brief moment we see this aspiring musician's soul opening up. But the admiration is not constant. Deep resentment follows. He cannot help but register deep disdain at the thought that he can never be Mozart. He is brought back to earth after the duration of the Mozart piece. The sheer pleasure of the fresh music has been a balm to his soul. His mood rapidly changes to one of anger when he is alone with himself. He curses his God, that he would choose one so crude, so unmannered and undeserving as that "boy". In this all consuming hatred he is gradually reduced to a shell of a man.Salieri has for years witnessed Mozart's prodigious talents, his rapid rise to prominence in the court of King Joseph II. Each time he is driven to this mixture of admiration and hatred. This drives Salieri to a new ambition. Since he is not born with talent, he can surely appropriate Mozart's genius as his own. Thus follows the devious part of the narrative. Salieri finds the opportunity to take advantage of Mozart's dire financial misfortunes and forces him to write a couple of operas so that he can pass it of as his own. Failing that, he will at least get a glimpse of what inspired composition entails.What follows is truly inspired cinema. I do not think there is a movie out there that shows the artist at work as movingly as it is shown here. Percy Adlon's Celeste comes close, and perhaps Minelli's Lust for Life. The especially poignant scenes show an admiring Salieri writing feverishly, hanging on to every instruction of an ailing Mozart. He is working the musician to death. Even when he is too weak to write, Salieri goads him on, willing to be dragged through the unexpected turns of Mozart's art of composition. Salieri is often confused in composition, but he meekly follows Mozart's instructions and copies down a wild sequence of musical notes. It is only after the tunes settle in his head, do we see a light go on in Salieri. We see this curious paradox of an envious autocrat and willing disciple gratefully clinging on to these insights in musical composition. When Salieri finally digests an inspired idea after a valient struggle, he is hushed by Mozart, since that is but the set up for the main sequence to follow. Thus we see Salieri bring dragged into the rigors of inspiration, the agonies of the work behind Mozart's magnum opus - the "Requiem". The soundtrack of Mozart's funereal dirge fills the room, as the musician faintly dictates the last notes to an increasingly elated Salieri. Salieri, in this final scene, is finally shown "composing" music as he had dreamed it, except that he is plugged into inspiration. Divinity in music is coming through that dying intermediary.The plight of the individual who is being refused into the mysteries of artistic creation has not been conceived in a film with as much pathos as in Salieri's life in Milos Foreman's Amadeus. In like measure Amadeus also shows the graces and curses that come with being a genius. Mozart's example shows that to have the gift of music can also be a terrible burden. Art ultimately defies destruction and it does indeed live longer than life. Salieri knows this, as his own life will testify. But he also knows that the beauty of Mozart's music is worth dying for, the gift Mozart is touched by is worth the destruction that inevitably visits the artist. In his marginalized role of sitting from afar Salieri witnesses genius while being acutely conscious of being condemned to the role of the admiring spectator.

reviewText: This movie is superbly produced and acted. One is transported back to those days of Patrons of the Arts and fashionable Salons ruled over by the matriarchs of local society.  Mozart doesn't come out of history with too much credit and for his sake, it might have been better had this film - and history generally - had skipped over his private life and character.  His music, on the other hand, lives on and delights all music lovers to this day. Mozart was certainly a paradox of supreme proportions.

reviewText: 5 stars for the Theatrical version. Hardly 2 stars for the DC release! Unfortunately, the Director's Cut has already done all the damage - whether one day the Theatrical version is released along with it or not. Just its existence was sufficient to have ruined the original Theatrical version. I no longer enjoy watching the original  having seen this new DC once. Whoever removed those out-of-place scenes from the movie in 1985 was brilliant. The movie in its original form was perfect and made all the points it wanted to make without a topless show or Mozart begging for money. It's beyond my comprehension how the same person who directed such a masterpiece wanted those awful scenes included.
summary: 5 Stars for the Theatrical Version, but 2 Stars for this DC Release

reviewText: I am not a very erudite reviewer of movies. I know however how highly praised this film is . I can understand why. Great music, and an amusing drama in which Envy plays a central role. The much wiser and worldly Salieri envies the dumb Mozart who produces works of genius that Salieri cannot. Salieri's intriguing and betrayal , his angry passion are at the heart of the story.I however watched the film wanting and waiting to understand where Mozart's genius comes from, and how it works. The point or one point of the film is that it is 'dumb genius' entirely.This is not true to Mozart's life as we know it. And in this I found the film wanting.
summary: The real Mozart is not here

reviewText: A visually gorgeous production, with fabulous staging and musical score.A pity the diction and accents are so mainstream modern, American, and totally out of synch with the historical  and cultural milieu.But greatly distorts history.Insane laugh is entirely inauthentic, and completely breaks the spell into cheap soap opera.Mozart was a musician, trained in vocal and musical composition from childhood.His own ear would not have tolerated the braying laugh as portrayed in the film.If you can get past that recurrent irritation, the film is wonderful musical pleasure.  F. Murray Abraham is GREAT!
summary: Mozart's other life, as seen by the brilliant composer he eclipsed,  Salieri!

reviewText: Superb performances all around.  Incredible story that keeps you watching, enthralled.  Beautiful music throughout.  Characters both flawed and admirable.  This film is simply a joy to watch.It has been around for quite a while now too!  It stands up to the test of time, revealing itself as a timeless gem of cinema.Amadeus is a fascinating, funny, thrilling drama.  You do not need to be a musician or artist to love this film.  It is the shocking, sometimes sad, journey of a master musician struggling to find his place within a back-stabbing foppish society littered with lesser musicians, jealous observers, and mobs of admirers.Did he drive himself insane?  Was he driven insane?  Was he actually insane?  Was he simply a man beyond his time?  Or is he an example of how close genius is to madness?Find out.  Watch it.  In fact, BUY IT.  You will re-watch this excellent film.  Just ask, Falco.
summary: "Amadeus, Amadeus, Oh , Oh, Oh, Amadeus" -- Falco
